risinfo.booktitle: Companion Animal End of Life Care for the Veterinary Technician

para.emphasis: Veterinary Technology Program, Dalhousie University, Bible Hill, NS, Canada

sect2.title: 8.1 Introduction
sect2.para: One of the most frequently asked questions to veterinary technicians in end‐of‐life (EOL) care is, “When is the right time for euthanasia?.” Caregivers of companion animals want to avoid making this decision “too early” when they could still have good quality time with their pet, but they also want to avoid making this decision “too late” when they could have spared their pet from unnecessary distress. A carefully considered decision where caregivers have a sense of control reduces the likelihood of decisional regret, which in turn supports a healthier grief process [ch0019-c8-bib-0001, ch0019-c8-bib-0002]. The reality is that there is no perfect “right” time. We must shift the perspective toward making the best or most reasonable decision for the family and the pet within their unique circumstances.

The discussion of euthanasia timing is becoming more complex as continued advances in diagnostics and treatment are made available and hospice‐supported natural death becomes more common. Decision‐making frameworks must balance caregiver considerations and animal welfarech0019-c8-bib-0003 with a focus on quality of life (QOL) rather than longevity ch0019-c8-bib-0004. Advising caregivers on EOL decisions is ultimately within the scope of the veterinarian. Euthanasia is a treatment that must be prescribed, and hospice‐supported natural death also requires veterinary supervision. With that said, veterinary technicians have important roles in EOL decision‐making, including caregiver education and communication, patient assessment, and liaising with the veterinarian and other members of the EOL care team. The involvement of knowledgeable and compassionate technicians in EOL decision‐making is invaluable for both the caregivers and the veterinary team.

Participation in EOL decision‐making is stressful for the veterinary team and is in fact reported to be more stressful than the euthanasia procedure itselfch0019-c8-bib-0005. This stress can be reduced using an ethical approach, seeking further information, and exchanging ideas and support with colleagues. The goal of ethical EOL decision‐making is for the caregiver to arrive at a decision that supports animal welfare within the reality of their circumstances, and one they may reflect on in the future without regret. Veterinary team members can consider their job well done if caregivers feel they have made the best possible informed decision at the best time they could have made it.

This chapter will discuss caregiver perspectives on EOL decision‐making, factors for the medical team to consider, communication guidance for the veterinary technician, and ethical dilemmas that may be encountered. Technicians must be sensitive to caregivers’ values, culture, and religious considerations, which may shape their perspectives on euthanasia and natural death. Hospice‐supported natural death is currently less common than euthanasia in companion animal EOL care, but it is possible and should be explored in discussion if the caregiver wishes. Chapter 9 examines hospice‐supported natural death in more detail.

sect2.title: 8.2 Communication in EOL Decision‐Making
sect2.para: Approaches to supporting EOL decision‐making range from paternalistic (the veterinarian provides their preferred course of action) to hands‐off (the veterinarian provides the facts only and it is up to the caregiver to make the decision). Between these two extremes are various forms of shared decision‐making, where the veterinary team partners with the caregiver to formulate a mutually agreed‐upon plan.

The paternalistic approach may unduly influence the caregiver and interfere with their autonomy in the decision‐making process. Caregivers may suppress concerns that could be decisive if the veterinary team pushes their own viewpoint without appropriately seeking the caregiver’s perspectivech0019-c8-bib-0006. For example, if a caregiver wishes to discuss euthanasia as an option and the veterinarian is focused on offering treatment plans, the caregiver may feel guilt or judgement and refrain from asking for euthanasia. Veterinarian‐driven decision‐making may also be associated with feelings of blame if the caregivers experience regret about the actions taken. In failing to gather the caregiver’s perspective, the veterinary team misses valuable information on the animal’s history, routine, and preferences, as well as the caregiver’s psychosocial considerations (see Chapter 1), which may be pivotal in the decision.

The “hands‐off,” facts‐only approach is where the veterinary team gives no indication of their preferred or recommended option. This could be argued as the only approach to truly autonomous decision‐making for the caregiver. However, if a purely factual approach is taken to advising caregivers on EOL decisions, they may not be able to determine which information is most important. Caregivers may need assistance in understanding the nuances and implications of the information. Interpretation of the facts by the veterinary team can provide crucial context for informed decision‐making. There is arguably no way for the veterinary team to avoid influencing decision‐making if they take care to thoroughly inform the caregiver. Thus, technicians should acknowledge that veterinary influence is an inherent part of the process and to try and be transparent and self‐aware.

Most experts on ethical clinical communication will agree that some form of shared decision‐making is the best approach. Shared decision‐making elicits the caregiver’s perspective, confirms understanding, and negotiates a mutually agreed‐upon plan. This perspective allows veterinary professionals to act as guides and partners in the decision‐making process. Preferences for the type and depth of the veterinary team’s involvement in decision‐making will differ between individuals. Some will need more guidance and emotional support, and others will prefer less input. The caregivers may simply be asked how much involvement they would like from the veterinary team in their decision‐making.

sect2.title: 8.3 Caregiver Perspectives on EOL Decision‐Making
sect2.para: Studies show that there is no consistent approach among veterinary teams in supporting euthanasia decision‐making. Not every caregiver feels empowered by their veterinary team or feels that their feelings and perspectives were effectively explored [ch0019-c8-bib-0003, ch0019-c8-bib-0007]. This demonstrates the importance of focusing on this component of EOL care as a priority for education, training and professional mentorship.

A 2016 study of caregiver perspectives on EOL found that caregivers wanted involvement from the veterinary team in the euthanasia decision‐making process for two reasons. First, they did not feel equipped to assess their pet’s condition or the implications of treatment options on their own. Second, they did not want the burden of making the decision alone (Pro Tip 8.1) ch0019-c8-bib-0006. Caregivers in this study reported that veterinary teams aided them in several ways such as providing expert knowledge and a professional assessment of the animal’s physical status. They appreciated when the veterinary team provided context and interpretation of medical information, and support or confirmation for the decisions they were about to make. If a caregiver is leaning toward euthanasia, the veterinary team showing support or reluctance for this choice can influence the caregiver’s decision in a way that gives them more confidence (Communication Corner 8.1).

The highest predictor of a euthanasia decision aside from patient QOL is caregiver burden. Financial considerations also play a significant role in euthanasia decisions [ch0019-c8-bib-0003, ch0019-c8-bib-0008]. Caregivers find it easier to make euthanasia decisions when there are clear welfare concerns (animal suffering, inability to function, not happy, frequently symptomatic) and/or when there is a perceived exhaustion of treatment options (e.g. a dog with hemangiosarcoma experiences major internal bleeding, or a cat with a brain tumor is experiencing prolonged and frequent seizures) ch0019-c8-bib-0006. Euthanasia decisions are more difficult for caregivers in cases of chronic illness with a slow progression or fluctuating illness without clear endpoints identified (e.g. cognitive dysfunction, progressive decline in mobility due to osteoarthritis, etc.) (see Pro Tip 8.2). The influence and emotional support of the veterinary team is more impactful in circumstances where the family is unsure of the most ethical and appropriate decision for themselves and their pet ch0019-c8-bib-0006.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 8.1 Sharing the Burden of EOL Decisions
sidebar.para: Caregivers want the involvement of their veterinary team in their EOL decision‐making. They want to ensure they are effectively informed and share the burden of the decision to give them confidence in their choice. Veterinary teams should engage in a shared decision‐making paradigm that involves guidance and partnership.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 8.1 Supporting EOL Decisions
sidebar.para: When caregivers ask if they are doing the “right” thing, or if this is the “right” time, reply with the word “best” in place of “right.”

listitem.para: Question: “Am I doing the right thing for my pet?”
Answer: “You are making the best possible decision you can for them.”
NEVER say: “You’ll know when it’s time.”

This puts the onus on the caregiver without properly informing them of how they should know. Caregivers may feel abandoned and experience increased anxiety and a lack of trust in their veterinary relationship.

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 8.2 Revisiting Euthanasia Discussions
sidebar.para: The perspectives and feelings of the family will change over time, as will the status of the animal and the context of the circumstances. If euthanasia has been discussed but delayed (by mutual agreement), it is important to revisit the discussion regularly. This ensures the veterinary team remains up to date and the family continues to feel supported.

sect2.para: Caregivers report that having more knowledge about their pet’s circumstances and disease(s) would improve their ability to make EOL decisionsch0019-c8-bib-0006. Thus, a good recommendation for veterinary teams is to ensure caregivers are well‐informed about their pet’s diagnoses, status, and possible progression of disease. This sounds straightforward but can be complex. Caregivers may require time to absorb and process the information, especially if it was provided in a high‐stress or emotional context (see Case Study 8.1). Discussions may need to occur with multiple family members or caregivers, and alternative sources of information may be sought to aid in understanding. This is much easier in situations where a euthanasia decision is a future consideration rather than imminent. In situations where welfare concerns support an immediate decision, the veterinary team will make the utmost effort to tend to the animal’s comfort while ensuring the caregivers feel prepared to make an informed decision.

sidebar.title: Case Study 8.1 Timber, Evan, and Robyn
sidebar.para: Dr. Bolton is a mobile hospice veterinarian who is called by a couple, Evan and Robyn, to request a home QOL evaluation of their 10‐year‐old husky, Timber. They took Timber to a general practice for an exam as they noticed he’d lost some weight. It seemed to them that he was doing fine otherwise, so they were shocked when the veterinarian told them that Timber was in poor condition and recommended euthanasia. With such devastating and unexpected news, Evan and Robyn were not ready to consent to euthanasia and asked to take Timber home. The veterinarian told them this was against medical advice and that they would be reported to the local humane society. They’ve called Dr. Bolton to help them understand what’s going on.

Dr. Bolton agrees to evaluate Timber that day and is able to speak to the general practice veterinarian in advance. Timber has been given a presumptive diagnosis of cardiac hemangiosarcoma (suspicion of right atrial mass on ultrasound with pericardial effusion) with indicators of cardiovascular instability (muffled heart sounds, pulse deficit) and emaciated body condition. The veterinarian stands by their recommendation for urgent euthanasia and is concerned about Timber’s welfare. They are relieved Dr. Bolton has become involved.

On arrival at Timber’s home, Dr. Bolton is greeted by the couple and Timber. Timber is interactive and able to walk but is moving quite slowly and stiffly. Dr. Bolton takes a few minutes to establish a rapport with Timber, Evan, and Robyn and confirm the recent history, but moves quickly to assess Timber. The exam findings include pale pink mucous membranes, muffled heart sounds, tachycardia, peripheral pulse deficits, a palpable splenic mass, and emaciation. Despite this, Timber is still interested in affection and moves about the room.

Dr. Bolton explains that their findings match that of the other veterinarian, and the presence of a palpable splenic mass along with the cardiovascular signs would correspond with a primary differential of hemangiosarcoma with pericardial effusion. Together, they discuss the reality of Timber’s cardiovascular instability and the poor long‐term prognosis associated with the likely diagnosis. The options for emergency intervention (emergency pericardiocentesis) and stabilization at an emergency center are discussed, as well as home euthanasia.

Evan and Robyn are grateful for the time and care taken to explain each of Timber’s clinical signs and the reasoning behind the presumptive diagnosis and recommendation for euthanasia from the previous veterinarian. With the second opinion and extended home consult, they now understand and agree that Timber’s QOL is poor. A home euthanasia is scheduled, and Dr. Bolton is able to report to the humane society and resolve the case file.

para.emphasis: Why might there have been such a disconnect or negative experience between the first veterinarian and this family?
could be used to resolve conflict and engage in shared decision making in similar situations?
What made Evan and Robyn accept Dr. Bolton’s assessment when they did not accept the first veterinarian’s assessment?
Which aspects of a home hospice consultation do you think were the most helpful in bringing this situation to a compassionate outcome?

sect2.para: Consider the situation where an appointment unexpectedly turns into a critical case and euthanasia or emergency surgery are the only available treatment options. For instance, a dog that has been hit by a car and has multiple pelvic fractures. A decision must be made urgently for euthanasia or emergency stabilization efforts and surgery. The veterinarian has other urgent cases they must attend to while the family takes time to process the diagnosis they have received and consider their options. The technician may be able to implement some stabilization and comfort measures under the veterinarian’s direction and support patient monitoring and caregiver communication while the veterinarian is otherwise engaged. The family will benefit from the guidance, medical information, and emotional support the technician provides as they absorb the information they’ve been given and consider their choices.

sect2.title: 8.3.1 Conflicting Caregiver Perspectives
sect2.para: Caregivers have trouble making EOL decisions when they have conflicting concerns. While finances are a common cause of internal conflict for caregivers, it may arise for multiple other reasons as well. Caregivers may struggle to decide whether the benefits of a proposed treatment plan outweigh any potential stress it may cause the pet (e.g. emergency surgery, oncology treatments, hospitalization, etc.). In circumstances where the need for humane euthanasia is approaching, caregivers may try to delay the decision because it is too emotionally difficult (seeCommunication Corner 8.2). Guilt is another source of internal conflict for caregivers, particularly when it comes to considering their own QOL and caregiver burden in decision‐making. Technicians can validate caregivers’ thoughts and feelings and provide medical context, guidance, and emotional support through these internal conflicts. Refer back to Chapter 6 for practical communication strategies to apply in these conversations. Other difficult conversations, such as those involving angry clients and conflict between caregivers were discussed in Chapter 7. Anticipatory grief will have some level of impact on most caregivers in EOL decision‐making as well. Part IV will offer technicians more insight and communication strategies for supporting caregivers with anticipatory grief.

sidebar.title: Communication Corner 8.2 Perspectives on Euthanasia
sidebar.para: You are a technician assisting with a QOL assessment. The family is likely to book euthanasia, but the primary caregiver is struggling with being the one to make the decision. They say, “I wish they would just go peacefully in their sleep.” How would you respond?

Technicians will find what feels authentic to them as they practice EOL communication. Some example responses are included. (SeeChapters 6 and 7 and Part IV for further EOL communication and grief support information.)

listitem.para: “This is not an easy to decision to make, but it is one you are making out of love.”
“This is a burden we can choose to bear to lessen theirs.”
“I think most of us would hope for what you have described, but it is unfortunately rare. A peaceful goodbye through euthanasia is a gift that we get to give.”

sect2.title: 8.4 Factors for Veterinary Team Consideration in EOL Decision‐Making
sect2.para: Making the best possible decision within each situation is challenging due to the number of factors to consider. Building an exact “roadmap” for EOL decisions is impossible, but veterinarians can carefully consider euthanasia decisions in part by referring to scientific definitions of animal welfarech0019-c8-bib-0009. Technicians supporting EOL conversations should consider whether an animal is functioning well, feeling well, and expressing behaviors normal for their species (or that individual). The American Veterinary Medical Association suggests that a euthanasia decision may be made when the animal is deemed to no longer have a “life worth living” ch0019-c8-bib-0009. When an animal’s negative experiences outweigh their positive experiences, the decision to provide a good death with euthanasia is warranted.

While an animal’s health status and welfare are the highest priorities in decision‐making, they are not the only considerations. The caregiver’s situation must also be consideredch0019-c8-bib-0002. A framework for ethical clinical decision‐making that is commonly used in human medicine is the “four topics” or four‐box method ch0019-c8-bib-0010. The four topics are: medical indications, caregiver and patient preferences, quality of life, and contextual features. They have been summarized and adapted for veterinary EOL decision‐making in Table 8.1.

sect2.title: 8.4.1 Quality‐of‐Life Assessments in EOL Decision‐Making
sect2.para: The use of structured QOL assessments in veterinary consultations can lead pet caregivers to feel emotionally empowered and improve their decision‐makingch0019-c8-bib-0011. QOL considers not only the physical function and comfort of the pet, but also their mental, social, and emotional wellness to consider if their life is one worth living. QOL assessment should be effectively incorporated into EOL decision‐making, with the approach and style of assessment tailored to the needs of the family and the pet as well as situational context (Pro Tip 8.3). A family considering euthanasia in a non‐urgent situation (e.g. slow decline of QOL with osteoarthritis) may be sent home with resources, multiple styles of assessment tools, and have a follow‐up phone consultation scheduled to discuss. By contrast, a family with a dog bleeding internally due to ruptured hemangiosarcoma must make an urgent decision to euthanize or proceed to emergency surgery. This will require a very different approach to QOL assessment and EOL decision‐making from the veterinary team. QOL and its assessment were covered in detail in Chapter 5.

Table 8.1
The four topics in ethical EOL decision‐making. Source: Adapted from Jonsen et al. ch0019-c8-bib-0010.

entry.para: What is/are the diagnosis/diagnoses? Is the patient stable or unstable? Are clinical signs controlled or uncontrolled? Is the disease reversible or terminal? What are the goals of care? What is the likelihood of treatment success? How can the patient be benefited, and harm avoided?

What level of veterinary involvement in decision‐making does the owner desire? Is everyone who should be involved in the decision‐making informed? Do the caregivers have sufficient information and understanding of the animal’s health status and progression? How is the animal accepting or cooperating with treatments?

Does the QOL assessment lead to any changes in the treatment plan? Does the current QOL require intervention? Is a return to normal function and behavior possible? Does the animal have a life worth living? What caregiver or veterinary biases might impact the QOL assessment? What could be done to improve the patient’s quality of life? Are there any ethical concerns with this approach?

Are there conflicts between caregivers or between the caregivers and veterinary team? What is the caregiver burden? Are the caregivers physically, temporally, financially, mentally, and emotionally able to provide the required nursing care? Are there any cultural or religious considerations that may impact end‐of‐life decision‐making? Are there any quarantine requirements impacting end of life decisions? (e.g. Rabies observation period following bite incident)

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 8.3 QOL Assessment Compliance
sidebar.para: Thorough QOL assessments are valuable tools in EOL decision‐making but can be time consuming and caregivers may not always comply with their use. Having caregivers track good, neutral, and bad days on a calendar is easy and quick. This provides simplified “data” to assess when the balance between positive and negative states is shifting.

sect2.title: 8.4.2 Caregiver Burden and EOL Decision‐Making
sect2.para: After animal QOL, caregiver burden is the highest predictor of a decision to euthanize. It is an important part of the four topics approach to ethical EOL decision‐making (seeTable 8.1). To effectively advise and support caregivers in EOL decision‐making, technicians must understand the caregivers’ burden. Caregiver burden encompasses more than just the direct strain of caring for the animal. It also involves stress and guilt from a variety of sources ch0019-c8-bib-0003. Caregivers may experience guilt about considering their own QOL in EOL decision‐making, but it is an important factor. Technicians play an important role in acknowledging the burden caregivers feel and legitimizing its inclusion as a factor in EOL decision‐making. Support from the veterinary team may help to dispel some of the guilt caregivers feel ch0019-c8-bib-0006.

Table 8.2
Questions to assess caregiver burden. Source: Adapted from Spitznagel et al. ch0019-c8-bib-0003.

entry.para: Do your pet’s care needs interfere with you having enough time for yourself? Does your pet’s care cause you stress in balancing your work and family needs? Does your pet’s care cause you to feel out of control of your life?
Do you ever feel angry or resentful towards your pet or their needs? Does your pet’s behavior cause you to feel embarrassed?
Do you feel like you are not doing enough for your pet? Do you feel you could be doing a better job of caring for your pet?

blockquote.para: Excess caregiver burden is a QOL concern for the caregiver.

para.emphasis: How might this also impact the pet’s quality of life?

sect2.para: People experiencing excess caregiver burden may show signs of excessive communication, conflict with the veterinary team or others, or noncompliance with prescribed treatments or follow‐upch0019-c8-bib-0003. These behaviors are also likely to cause stress for the veterinary team, so identifying them as possible hallmarks of caregiver burden and initiating a conversation with the caregiver is beneficial for everyone involved. It is recommended that regular assessment of caregiver burden be included as part of monitoring an EOL care plan through to and including euthanasia decision making (see Table 8.2). Chapter 5 includes examples of QOL assessments that also assess caregiver burden.

Unacknowledged caregiver burden may be a contributor to early decisions to euthanize (before it is medically necessary). In recognizing and addressing caregiver burden, technicians play a significant role in preventing early euthanasia. Identifying the causes behind excess caregiver burden may allow for some of them to be resolved and improve the situation. This may involve further caregiver education, accessing financial resources or relief care, or referrals to mental health providers such as veterinary social workers. If the causes of excess caregiver burden cannot be addressed, then the discussion may lead toward a decision for euthanasia.

sect2.title: 8.4.3 Caregiver Preferences and Euthanasia Timing
sect2.para: When a family has a strong vision for their pet’s transition to death, it may end up influencing some of their decision‐making. For instance, if a caregiver hates the idea of having to rush into a 24‐hour veterinary hospital for an emergency euthanasia, they may choose to euthanize before it would be absolutely medically necessary in order to have control over the circumstances. Another family may envision a humane euthanasia with the entire family present, outside on the farm where the pet has lived its whole life. This may similarly motivate a decision to plan euthanasia earlier than is medically necessary to fulfill this vision. Other caregivers may be less concerned about the circumstances and timing of euthanasia and wish instead to focus on whatever quality time they can spend with their pet until QOL changes necessitate an EOL decision. Understanding the caregivers’ concerns and values allow EOL care teams to plan and provide supports to realize their vision for their pet’s transition. Technicians may be able to help caregivers plan a more beautiful goodbye than they realized was possible. For example, not all caregivers are aware that home euthanasia is possible and that alone may completely change their decision making. A family may be concerned about a sudden decline at home and plan an early euthanasia until a technician mentions the concept of a comfort kit and offers information on home euthanasia (see Pro Tip 8.4).

sidebar.title: Pro Tip 8.4 Comfort Kits as a Factor in EOL Decisions
sidebar.para: The use of comfort kits can be a significant factor in EOL decision‐making. Caregivers may feel stressed about the possibility of their pet experiencing a sudden change in status at home and feeling powerless to help them in this situation. This may lead to decisions to euthanize earlier to reduce the likelihood of this circumstance.

EOL care teams that dispense comfort kits of injectable sedation and pain relief for use at home may see that this changes the caregiver’s feelings on euthanasia planning. They may be more comfortable taking some additional quality time with their companion knowing that they have a way to provide comfort at home if circumstances change quickly. SeeChapters 3 (Pain Management) and 4 (Hospice and Palliative Nursing Care) for more information and guidance on the appropriate use of comfort kits.

sect2.para: Technicians can inquire about and legitimize these caregiver perspectives in EOL decision‐making. Some situations may be less about preferences and more about changing circumstances within a caregiver’s life. For instance, a cat may be doing well in hospice care for chronic kidney insufficiency, but does not travel well, and the family is planning an international move in two months. Their concern for the stress of travel and adjustment to new circumstances may influence the family’s vision for their pet’s EOL transition and lead them to a euthanasia decision prior to moving.

sect2.title: 8.5 Considerations for Hospice‐Supported Natural Death
sect2.para: The topic of hospice‐supported natural death will be discussed in more detail inChapter 9, but is important to consider in the context of EOL decision‐making. Families who wish to explore this option deserve the same level of information, discussion, and support as any family requesting euthanasia. Veterinary teams not comfortable with providing hospice‐supported natural death due to a lack of knowledge and experience should share this with families but still aim to support their discussion. They may wish to refer caregivers requesting this option to a certified hospice and palliative veterinarian or a mobile veterinary service that focuses on EOL care.

Even if your practice is not familiar or comfortable with supervising hospice‐supported natural death, it is worth knowing something about it so that you can help educate caregivers. In the context of ethical EOL decision‐making, natural death must be supported by palliative care. If supporting a natural death is preferred over euthanasia, this must be done with veterinary guidance to ensure that the animal’s welfare is effectively attended to throughout the dying process. This includes multi‐modal analgesia, clinical sign relief, general comfort nursing care, and possible palliative sedation.

Proper provision of hospice‐supported natural death requires significant knowledge and team caregiving efforts (potentially 24/7 in the final days). This can be logistically challenging and expensive. Hospice‐supported natural death may not be available in all areas to all caregivers due to a lack of knowledgeable and trained veterinary providers. Even where veterinary providers are available, it may not be reasonable for caregivers to financially commit to the nursing care and veterinary supervision required. There is often a mismatch between a family’s desires for their pet’s EOL care and the financial and logistical realities. It is recommended to provide detailed forecasting of the financial commitments associated with hospice‐supported natural death to best support effective decision‐makingch0019-c8-bib-0012.

Ethical provision of hospice‐supported natural death is accompanied by an agreement that euthanasia may still need to occur if the caregiving team is unable to effectively manage animal welfare. Veterinary teams offering hospice‐supported natural death must thoroughly communicate the realities and requirements of ethical natural death and have specifics regarding this in their informed consent documentation. Veterinary teams must also be prepared to terminate client relationships if they are not able to negotiate a mutually agreed‐upon ethical plan. Refer toChapter 9 for more discussion of considerations for hospice‐supported natural death and nursing care of dying patients.

sect2.title: 8.6 Ethical Dilemmas and Moral Stress
sect2.para: Shared EOL decision‐making which respects caregiver autonomy is the recommended approach, but there is a potential conflict that can arise when caregiver autonomy and patient welfare are not fully alignedch0019-c8-bib-0006. Given that the animal cannot directly express their own wishes, the caregivers make decisions on their behalf. The veterinary team has an obligation to advocate on the patient’s behalf and for the patient’s welfare when participating in shared decision‐making. This can create tension when the veterinary team’s obligation to the caregiver and their obligation to the animal are in conflict, resulting in an ethical dilemma. Effective communication can hopefully expose and resolve conflicts gently ch0019-c8-bib-0004, but ethical dilemmas may still arise despite a technician’s best efforts.

Ethical dilemmas in EOL care cause stress for technicians and can interfere with job satisfaction and well‐being. Many veterinarians face ethical dilemmas weekly, with 34% reporting they faced 3–5 per week and 19% reporting daily ethical dilemmas [ch0019-c8-bib-0013, ch0019-c8-bib-0014]. The most common ethical dilemmas around euthanasia involve finances, where veterinary teams report performing euthanasia based primarily on financial limitations somewhere between once monthly and once weekly ch0019-c8-bib-0014. Teams may also face dilemmas involving caregivers wishing to continue treatment despite poor animal welfare.

Ethical dilemmas in EOL care outside of finances generally fall into two categories: 1) caregivers wishing to euthanize an animal when it is not deemed medically appropriate, and 2) caregivers declining to euthanize an animal when it is deemed medically necessary to prevent unnecessary sufferingch0019-c8-bib-0002. In the first case, the veterinarian has an ethical obligation to prevent unnecessary animal distress. They may need to push for an EOL decision even if the caregiver is not ready. A veterinarian cannot force a caregiver to proceed with euthanasia (although they could consider reporting an owner to local authorities if the situation warranted this). The second type of dilemma allows the veterinarian the opportunity to decline to perform euthanasia if they feel this is the most ethical response. Eighty percent of veterinarians report declining to perform euthanasia at some point in their career ch0019-c8-bib-0014, but this is infrequent overall ch0019-c8-bib-0015. It is important to acknowledge that everyone’s circumstances are different, and we can never be fully informed about another’s context for their decision‐making. The decisions we will make for ourselves will often differ from those made by others in similar situations. Decisions that differ from your own opinions are not necessarily unethical. The general public lacks the knowledge, skills, and access to care that veterinary professionals possess, making it difficult to compare our decision‐making to that of the caregivers we advise. What seems ethical to one individual may not be perceived as ethically acceptable by another.

para.emphasis: What are your personal experiences and biases around euthanasia and EOL care decisions?

blockquote.para: Self‐awareness can help prevent you from bringing these biases into your work.

para.emphasis: Can you think of an EOL situation that would make you uncomfortable, but you could accept it as ethical for others in their own circumstances?
Is there a situation where you would decline to be involved due to an ethical boundary?
How will you respond if this occurs in your work as a technician?

sect2.title: 8.6.1 Convenience Euthanasia
sect2.para: Convenience euthanasia has been defined as “circumstances where the primary rationale for this request is based on human needs such as economics, changes in personal circumstances, lack of time, capacity or desire to care for the animal, rather than animal welfare”ch0019-c8-bib-0014. This definition does not effectively account for the complexities of animal hospice. It overlaps with multiple contexts where decisions to euthanize would be considered ethically sound if we legitimize the inclusion of caregiver psychosocial considerations in EOL decision‐making. How an individual veterinary professional or team defines convenience euthanasia within their work may differ. You and your team must discuss what you consider to be convenience euthanasia and how you would approach those cases.

An example was previously given of a cat with kidney disease in hospice care whose family is moving internationally in two months. They may choose to euthanize before it would be strictly medically necessary to spare the cat the stress of travel and adjustment to a new home. This is a very different situation from one where the cat was healthy, and the family decided it would be too expensive and stressful for the cat to travel. If they were asking for euthanasia in this circumstance, this would present more of an ethical dilemma as a convenience euthanasia. It was previously mentioned that the majority of veterinarians have declined to perform euthanasia at some point in their career, although it is rare within a given professional’s experience. Convenience euthanasia of a healthy animal, or an animal with a good prognosis is likely when these refusals occur.

sect2.title: 8.7 EOL Decision Documentation and Debriefing
sect2.para: Euthanasia records in veterinary practices are often very basic and may not contain documentation of the decision‐making process beyond a simplified reason for euthanasia. This limits the ability to review the situational context when there are disagreements or concerns following a decision to euthanizech0019-c8-bib-0016. Documentation also allows for more effective team debriefing, mentorship, and discussion with colleagues. Comparing notes and discussing challenging cases with colleagues allows veterinary professionals to learn from each other and offers important moral support ch0019-c8-bib-0002. Technicians should take care to document their EOL discussions with caregivers including the treatment options explored, caregiver context and perspective, and the provision of grief resources.

listitem.para: Caregivers want the involvement of the veterinary team in EOL decision‐making. This includes education about their pet’s status and future progression, the context and implications of treatment options, and confirmation of their decisions.
To be effective in supporting EOL decision‐making, technicians require ethical frameworks, communication skills, and QOL assessment knowledge.
Caregiver burden is a crucial factor in EOL decision‐making and must be acknowledged, validated, and explored.
Technicians will advocate for patient welfare in EOL decision‐making, while remaining nonjudgmental.
Technicians should document their involvement in EOL decision‐making discussions in the medical record.
